original.title: Book VII: The Allegory of the Cave
original.preview: Socrates: And now, let me show in a figure how far our nature is enlightened or unenlightened.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And now, let me show in a figure how far our nature is enlightened or unenlightened.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Behold! Human beings living in an underground den, which has a mouth open towards the light and reaching all along the den; here they have been from their childhood, and have their legs and necks chained so that they cannot move, and can only see before them.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Above and behind them a fire is blazing at a distance, and between the fire and the prisoners there is a raised way; and you will see, if you look, a low wall built along the way, like the screen which marionette players have in front of them, over which they show the puppets.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I see.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And do you see men passing along the wall carrying all sorts of vessels, and statues and figures of animals made of wood and stone and various materials, which appear over the wall? Some of them are talking, others silent.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: You have shown me a strange image, and they are strange prisoners.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Like ourselves. And they see only their own shadows, or the shadows of one another, which the fire throws on the opposite wall of the cave.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True; how could they see anything but the shadows if they were never allowed to move their heads?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And of the objects which are being carried in like manner they would only see the shadows?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if they were able to converse with one another, would they not suppose that they were naming what was actually before them?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: To them, the truth would be literally nothing but the shadows of the images.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That is certain.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And now look again, and see what will naturally follow if the prisoners are released and disabused of their error.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: At first, when any of them is liberated and compelled suddenly to stand up and turn his neck round and walk and look towards the light, he will suffer sharp pains; the glare will distress him, and he will be unable to see the realities of which in his former state he had seen the shadows.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And then conceive someone saying to him, that what he saw before was an illusion, but that now, when he is approaching nearer to being and his eye is turned towards more real existence, he has a clearer vision—what will be his reply?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And you may further imagine that his instructor is pointing to the objects as they pass and requiring him to name them—will he not be perplexed? Will he not fancy that the shadows which he formerly saw are truer than the objects which are now shown to him?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Far truer.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if he is compelled to look straight at the light, will he not have a pain in his eyes which will make him turn away to take refuge in the objects of vision which he can see, and which he will conceive to be in reality clearer than the things which are now being shown to him?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And suppose once more, that he is reluctantly dragged up a steep and rugged ascent, and held fast until he is forced into the presence of the sun himself, is he not likely to be pained and irritated?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When he approaches the light his eyes will be dazzled, and he will not be able to see anything at all of what are now called realities.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Not all in a moment.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: He will require to grow accustomed to the sight of the upper world. And first he will see the shadows best, next the reflections of men and other objects in the water, and then the objects themselves.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then he will gaze upon the light of the moon and the stars and the spangled heaven; and he will see the sky and the stars by night better than the sun or the light of the sun by day.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Last of all he will be able to see the sun, and not mere reflections of him in the water, but he will see him in his own proper place, and not in another; and he will contemplate him as he is.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: He will then proceed to argue that this is he who gives the seasons and the years, and is the guardian of all that is in the visible world, and in a certain way the cause of all things which he and his fellows have been accustomed to behold.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Clearly, he would first see the sun and then reason about him.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And when he remembered his old habitation, and the wisdom of the den and his fellow-prisoners, do you not suppose that he would felicitate himself on the change, and pity them?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly, he would.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if they were in the habit of conferring honours among themselves on those who were quickest to observe the passing shadows and to remark which of them went before, and which followed after, and which were together—do you think that he would care for such honours and glories?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, I think that he would rather suffer anything than entertain these false notions and live in this miserable manner.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Imagine once more such an one coming suddenly out of the sun to be replaced in his old situation; would he not be certain to have his eyes full of darkness?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: To be sure.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if there were a contest, and he had to compete in measuring the shadows with the prisoners who had never moved out of the den, while his sight was still weak, would he not be ridiculous?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Men would say of him that up he went and down he came without his eyes; and that it was better not even to think of ascending; and if any one tried to loose another and lead him up to the light, let them only catch the offender, and they would put him to death.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No question.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: This entire allegory, you may now append, dear Glaucon, to the previous argument; the prison-house is the world of sight, the light of the fire is the sun.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And you will not misapprehend me if you interpret the journey upwards to be the ascent of the soul into the intellectual world according to my poor belief.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But, whether true or false, my opinion is that in the world of knowledge the idea of good appears last of all, and is seen only with an effort.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And, when seen, is also inferred to be the universal author of all things beautiful and right, parent of light and of the lord of light in this visible world, and the immediate source of reason and truth in the intellectual.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And that this is the power upon which he who would act rationally, either in public or private life must have his eye fixed.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I agree, as far as I am able to understand you.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Moreover, you must not wonder that those who attain to this beatific vision are unwilling to descend to human affairs; for their souls are ever hastening into the upper world where they desire to dwell.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, very natural.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And is there anything surprising in one who passes from divine contemplations to the evil state of man, misbehaving himself in a ridiculous manner?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Anything but surprising.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Any one who has common sense will remember that the bewilderments of the eyes are of two kinds, and arise from two causes, either from coming out of the light or from going into the light.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: This is equally true of the mind's eye; and he who remembers this when he sees any one whose vision is perplexed and weak, will not be too ready to laugh.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That is a very just distinction.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But then, if I am right, certain professors of education must be wrong when they say that they can put a knowledge into the soul which was not there before, like sight into blind eyes.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: They undoubtedly say this.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Whereas, our argument shows that the power and capacity of learning exists in the soul already; and that just as the eye was unable to turn from darkness to light without the whole body, so too the instrument of knowledge can only by the movement of the whole soul be turned from the world of becoming into that of being.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then, the business of us who are the founders of the State will be to compel the best minds to attain that knowledge which we have already shown to be the greatest of all—they must continue to ascend until they arrive at the good.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But when they have ascended and seen enough we must not allow them to do as they do now.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What do you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I mean that they remain in the upper world: but this must not be allowed; they must be made to descend again among the prisoners in the den, and partake of their labours and honours, whether they are worth having or not.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: But is not this unjust? Ought we to give them a worse life, when they might have a better?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You have again forgotten, my friend, the intention of the legislator, who did not aim at making any one class in the State happy above the rest; the happiness was to be in the whole State.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: He held the citizens together by persuasion and necessity, making them benefactors of the State, and therefore benefactors of one another; to this end he created them, not to please themselves, but to be his instruments in binding up the State.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True, I had forgotten.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Observe, Glaucon, that there will be no injustice in compelling our philosophers to have a care and providence of others.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: We shall explain to them that in other States, men of their class are not obliged to share in the toils of politics: and this is reasonable, for they grow up at their own sweet will, and the government would rather not have them.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But we have brought you into the world to be rulers of the hive, kings of yourselves and of the other citizens, and have educated you far better and more perfectly than they have been educated.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Quite true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Wherefore each of you, when his turn comes, must go down to the general underground abode, and get the habit of seeing in the dark. When you have acquired the habit, you will see ten thousand times better than the inhabitants of the den.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And you will know what the several images are, and what they represent, because you have seen the beautiful and just and good in their truth.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And thus our State which is also yours will be a reality, and not a dream only, and will be administered in a spirit unlike that of other States, in which men fight with one another about shadows only and are distracted in the struggle for power.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Quite true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Whereas the truth is that the State in which the rulers are most reluctant to govern is always the best and most quietly governed, and the State in which they are most eager, the worst.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Quite true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And will our pupils, when they hear this, refuse to take their turn at the toils of State, when they are allowed to spend the greater part of their time with one another in the heavenly light?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Impossible, for they are just men, and the commands which we impose upon them are just.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yes, my friend; and there lies the point. You must contrive for your future rulers another and a better life than that of a ruler, and then you may have a well-ordered State.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: For only in the State which offers this, will they rule who are truly rich, not in silver and gold, but in virtue and wisdom, which are the true blessings of life.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Most true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And now shall we consider in what way such guardians will be produced, and how they are to be brought from darkness to light—as some are said to have ascended from the world below to the gods?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: By all means.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And should we not enquire what sort of knowledge has the power of effecting such a change?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What sort of knowledge is there which would draw the soul from becoming to being?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: A something which all arts and sciences and intelligences use in common, and which every one first has to learn among the elements of education.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What is that?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The little matter of distinguishing one, two, and three—in a word, number and calculation. Do not all arts and sciences necessarily partake of them?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then this is knowledge of the kind for which we are seeking, having a double use, military and philosophical; for the man of war must learn the art of number or he will not know how to array his troops.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the philosopher also, because he has to rise out of the sea of change and lay hold of true being, and therefore he must be an arithmetician.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That is true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And next, shall we enquire whether the kindred science also concerns us? You mean geometry?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Exactly so.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then, my noble friend, geometry will draw the soul towards truth, and create the spirit of philosophy, and raise up that which is now unhappily allowed to fall down.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Nothing will be more likely to have such an effect.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And suppose we make astronomy the third—what do you say?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I am strongly inclined to it; the observation of the seasons and of months and years is as essential to the general as it is to the farmer or sailor.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I am amused at your fear of the world, which makes you guard against the appearance of insisting upon useless studies.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And I quite admit the difficulty of believing that in every man there is an eye of the soul which, when by other pursuits lost and dimmed, is by these purified and re-illumined; and is more precious far than ten thousand bodily eyes, for by it alone is truth seen.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I think that I should prefer to carry on the argument mainly on my own behalf.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then geometry will draw the soul towards truth, and create the spirit of philosophy.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Nothing will be more likely to have such an effect.

modern.title: Book VII: The Cave
modern.preview: Socrates: Let me show you how enlightened—or unenlightened—human nature really is.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let me show you how enlightened—or unenlightened—human nature really is.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Picture this: People living in an underground cave. There's an opening toward the light, but they've been chained there since childhood—legs and necks locked in place so they can only look straight ahead.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Behind them, a fire is burning. Between the fire and the prisoners is a raised walkway with a low wall—like the screen puppeteers use.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I can picture it.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now imagine people walking along that wall, carrying all kinds of objects—statues, animal figures made of wood and stone—that stick up above the wall. Some are talking, some are silent.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That's a strange image. Strange prisoners.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They're just like us. All they can see are their own shadows, or shadows of each other, cast on the cave wall by the fire.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True—how could they see anything else if they can't turn their heads?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the objects being carried past—they'd only see the shadows of those too, right?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yeah.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If they could talk to each other, wouldn't they assume the shadows were real things?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Definitely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: For them, truth would literally be nothing but shadows.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That's certain.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now think about what happens if one of them is released and forced to stand up, turn around, and walk toward the light.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: At first, it would hurt. The light would be blinding. He wouldn't be able to see the real objects—he'd only known their shadows before.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Imagine someone telling him: 'What you saw before was an illusion. Now you're closer to reality and seeing more clearly.' What would he think?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if someone pointed at the actual objects and asked him to name them—wouldn't he be totally confused? Wouldn't he think the shadows were more real than these new things?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Way more real.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if he's forced to look directly at the light, won't it hurt so much that he turns back to the shadows—the things he can actually see—thinking they're clearer than what's being shown to him?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now imagine he's dragged up a steep, rough path and forced out into the sunlight. He'd be pained and angry, right?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The brightness would be overwhelming. At first, he couldn't see anything at all.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Not right away.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: He'd need time to adjust. First he'd see shadows, then reflections in water, then actual objects.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then he could look at the night sky—the moon, the stars. That would be easier than looking at the sun during the day.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Makes sense.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Finally, he'd be able to look at the sun itself—not just its reflection, but the actual sun in its proper place.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And he'd realize that the sun is responsible for the seasons and years, that it governs everything in the visible world—that it's the cause of everything he and his fellow prisoners used to see.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Clearly, he'd see the sun first and then figure out what it means.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When he remembered his old home in the cave, and the 'wisdom' of his fellow prisoners, wouldn't he feel lucky about the change? Wouldn't he pity them?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Definitely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If the prisoners used to give awards to whoever was best at predicting which shadows would come next—would he care about those honors anymore?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No way. He'd rather suffer anything than go back to that life.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now imagine he goes back down into the cave. His eyes would be full of darkness again, right?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: For sure.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if he had to compete with the prisoners at identifying shadows while his eyes were still adjusting, wouldn't he look ridiculous?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They'd say: 'He went up there and came back blind! It's not worth even trying to go up.' And if anyone tried to free them and lead them up, they'd kill him if they could.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Absolutely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now, Glaucon, connect this whole allegory to our earlier discussion. The cave is the visible world. The fire's light is the sun.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The journey upward is the soul's ascent into the intellectual world—that's my interpretation, anyway.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: In the world of knowledge, the idea of the Good is the last thing you see, and it takes real effort.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But once you see it, you realize it's the source of everything beautiful and right—the parent of light in the visible world, and the source of reason and truth in the intellectual world.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Anyone who wants to act rationally, in public or private life, has to keep their eye fixed on this.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I agree, as far as I can understand you.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And don't be surprised that people who reach this vision don't want to come back to human affairs. Their souls are always rushing toward that higher world.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That makes sense.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And is it surprising that someone who goes from divine contemplation back to human misery seems awkward and ridiculous?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Not at all.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Anyone with sense knows that eyes can be confused in two ways: coming from light into darkness, or from darkness into light.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The same is true of the mind. When you see someone confused, don't laugh—ask whether they're coming from brightness or going toward it.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That's a fair distinction.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So those teachers who claim they can put knowledge into souls that don't have it—like giving sight to blind eyes—they're wrong.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: They definitely say that.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But our argument shows that the power to learn already exists in the soul. Just like the eye can't turn from darkness to light without the whole body turning, the mind can only move from appearances to reality when the whole soul turns.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So as founders of this state, our job is to force the best minds to pursue the highest knowledge—to keep climbing until they reach the Good.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But once they've seen it, we can't let them stay up there.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What do you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They have to go back down to the cave. They have to share in the prisoners' work and honors, whether those are worth having or not.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: But isn't that unfair? Why give them a worse life when they could have a better one?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You're forgetting our purpose. The lawgiver isn't trying to make one class super happy—the goal is happiness for the whole state.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: He uses persuasion and necessity to bind citizens together, making them benefit each other. They weren't created to please themselves, but to unite the state.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Right, I forgot that.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Look, Glaucon—it's not unjust to make our philosophers take care of others.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: In other states, philosophers aren't required to participate in politics—and that's fair because they educated themselves. The government doesn't want them.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But we raised you to be rulers, kings of yourselves and of others. We educated you far better than philosophers elsewhere.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So each of you must take turns going back down to the cave. Get used to the darkness. Once you adjust, you'll see ten thousand times better than the people who live there.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You'll understand what the shadows really are because you've seen truth, beauty, and goodness firsthand.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And our state will be real, not just a dream. Unlike other states where people fight over shadows and struggle for power.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Here's the truth: The state where rulers least want to govern is always the best governed. The state where they're eager for power is the worst.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: So true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Will our students refuse to take their turn at governing when they get to spend most of their time in the light?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No—they're just people, and our commands are just.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Exactly. The key is this: you have to offer your rulers a better life than being a ruler. Only then will you have a well-governed state.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Because only in that state will the truly rich rule—rich not in money, but in virtue and wisdom, which are the real treasures of life.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Absolutely true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now, how do we produce these guardians? How do we bring them from darkness to light?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Let's figure it out.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What kind of knowledge has the power to make this transformation?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Good question.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What draws the soul from the world of change to the world of being?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There's something that all arts and sciences use, something everyone has to learn first.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What is it?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The simple matter of distinguishing one, two, three—numbers and calculation. Every field uses them.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So arithmetic has a double purpose—military and philosophical. A general needs it to organize troops.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And a philosopher needs it to rise above the sea of change and grasp true being.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Makes sense.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What about geometry?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Definitely relevant.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Geometry draws the soul toward truth and creates the spirit of philosophy.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Nothing's more likely to have that effect.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And astronomy as the third subject?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I'm into it. Understanding seasons and time is essential for generals, farmers, and sailors.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I'm amused that you're worried about looking like you're pushing 'useless' studies.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But I believe that in everyone there's an eye of the soul. When other pursuits dim it, these studies purify and re-light it. That eye is worth more than ten thousand physical eyes—it's the only way to see truth.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I'll take your word for it.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So geometry will draw the soul toward truth and create the philosophical spirit.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Nothing's more likely to do that.
